title: 109_hr2658
content: The Act is titled the "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2005" and its purpose is stated in Section 2. The "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2005" clarifies Federal jurisdiction over waters of the United States, ensuring isolated wetlands without a significant nexus to navigable waters are regulated by states. It aims to provide consistency nationwide and consolidate administrative authority in one Federal agency. The "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2005" clarifies Federal authority to determine waters subject to permitting programs and protects states' rights to regulate wetlands and other waters within their jurisdiction. The "Federal Wetlands Jurisdiction Act of 2005" clarifies Federal authority over waters subject to permitting programs. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify jurisdiction over waters subject to permitting programs, including navigable waters, connected waters, and adjacent wetlands. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify jurisdiction over waters subject to permitting programs, including navigable waters, connected waters, and adjacent wetlands. Waters connected to navigable waters by perennial or intermittent streams are considered connected. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify jurisdiction over waters connected by surface water connections such as sheet flow, ephemeral waters, groundwater, manmade ditches, pipelines, or storm sewer systems. Connecting waters described shall not be subject to jurisdiction. The Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to clarify jurisdiction over connecting waters, which shall not be subject to the permitting program established by this section. The Act clarifies that States have the right to control discharge in wetlands and waters within their jurisdiction. It also grants the Secretary sole authority to determine the waters subject to the permitting program. Section 404(a) of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act grants individuals the right to request the Secretary to determine the presence of waters of the United States on their property. The Secretary may request additional information within 30 days of receiving the request. The Secretary may request additional information within 30 days of receiving a request. Within 90 days of receiving a request or 60 days after receiving additional information, the Secretary must make a jurisdictional determination and provide written notification to the requester. Any person authorized under paragraph (4) may seek immediate judicial review of a jurisdictional determination for property in the United States District Court or proceed through the administrative appeals process. Injunctive relief or administrative appeal may be sought for specified waters under paragraph (2)(A)(i), (2)(A)(ii), or (2)(A)(iii) as requested in paragraph (4). Those who choose the administrative appeals process can still seek judicial review in the United States District Court for the final decision of the Secretary. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. Section 404 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include definitions for "adjacent wetlands," "culvert," and "fastlands." Adjacent wetlands are wetlands touching a specified water source, culvert refers to a structure conveying streams under linear structures, and fastlands are areas within manmade structures like levees. The term 'navigable' refers to water used for transportation, 'sheet flow' is non-channelized water over upland, and 'wetlands' are lands with hydric soils that are inundated. Wetlands are areas with hydric soils that are regularly saturated by water, supporting vegetation adapted to wet conditions like swamps and marshes.
